captions.text: If you really want to understand
How the universe ticks
The LHC is what you need
We're about to go back to the beginning of time
The time when the Higgs ruled the universe
It will change our understanding of the cosmos
We want to know
Why things are the way they are
(We want to know)
How they work - what everything is
What is mass? Why does it exist?
Particles acquire mass by interacting with the Higgs field
The Higgs mechanism works by filling the universe with a field
If you gonna go for the big questions
you have to go for it
That what science at the Large Hadron Collider is all about
We can stare at the face of creation
Smash matter together
At energies never before achieved
(We can stare at the face of creation)
A beam of protons going that way
At almost the speed of light
Another beam of protons going that way
At almost the speed of light
They'll cross inside ATLAS
And recreate the conditions that were present
Just after the beginning of the universe
(Beginning of the universe)
We can stare at the face of creation
Smash matter together
At energies never before achieved
(We're about to go back to the beginning of time)
[Transcription: Vojtěch Pacík]

comments.text:
When it is the space that is stretching, you're not actually going faster 
than the speed of light, because you're not moving in space at all. Space 
is moving around you.

comments.text:
+Mr Quasar No, you're wrong, but that's okay.
The Higgs Boson was theorised a while ago, but not as early as the 1900's, 
closer to the 1960's actually. That was theorised but not proven the 
existence of. So yeah - we sort of knew it existed, but we were only 99% 
sure. In 2012 we observed it directly, discovered it properly, and as such 
are 100% sure it exists now.
comments.author: Kami K (Kolo)

comments.text:
Think of it as a very large, very expensive digital camera. There are a 
number of them, but ATLAS is the one Prof. Cox works on, and as Keiko said, 
it's where they can record the impacts and produce the data.
comments.author: Paul Barlow

comments.text:
He said "Inside ATLAS". If I recall correctly, that is the probable, 
quantum range in which the scientists placed as the observable area in 
which results were bound to happen.

That was how they were able to discover the higgs boson.

comments.author: Sanwal Yousaf

comments.text:
“How is it that hardly any major religion has looked at science and 
concluded, “This is better than we thought! The Universe is much bigger 
than our prophets said, grander, more subtle, more elegant. God must be 
even greater than we dreamed!”? Instead they say, “No, no, no! My god is a 
little god, and I want him to stay that way.” A religion, old or new, that 
stressed the magnificence of the Universe as revealed by modern science 
might be able to draw forth reserves of reverence and awe hardly tapped by 
the conventional faiths.”

― Carl Sagan, Pale Blue Dot: A Vision of the Human Future in Space

It would seem that Ken Ham, along with his other fellow young earth 
creationists, has a little god, and he wants him to stay that way.
comments.author: Scott Hulslander
